comments:
This course covers a brief review of High School calculus, then applications of
integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, Taylor's
theorem, and the use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.
Overall, students seemed to be neutral about this course, calling it “okay” and
“fine.” Some students, however, did find it “interesting” and “took a lot away from it.”
Students generally felt that Professor Jow was “not the most stimulating teacher,”
but that he “gets the job done” and is very knowledgeable.
Students found homework challenging, but the course as not too difficult overall.
Most students would not recommend this course if one only has a “fleeting interest in
mathematics.”

This course includes a brief review of high school calculus, applications of
integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, and Taylor's
theorem. Use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus is also taught.
Students described this course as “very informative” and “important” in that “there
are a lot of essential mathematical concepts taught;” however, overall students did not
find the course to be interesting. One student noted that the course would have benefited
from a “more comprehensive review of integrals and derivatives.”
Students were very divided in their evaluations of Dr. Lieberman. It seems as
though students who could keep up with him appreciated his “efficient” use of time in
class, “getting through numerous examples very quickly and succinctly.” More students,
however, found him to be an ineffective communicator of the material and noted that he
was too “theoretical” and moved too quickly for students to understand. One student
appreciated his “dry sense of humor,” but others found his lectures to be boring as they
were “word for word from the book.” Students did concede that he was “very nice and
understanding,” though.
This course satisfies the Formal Reasoning requirement. Students generally found
this class “difficult” and “fast paced.” Several students reported having to rely on their
previous knowledge of the material, and they found the new material difficult to grasp.
Tests were described as “hard,” and students reported having to do a lot of work for the
class, particularly in going through the textbook on their own.

This course is a brief review of High School calculus, applications of integrals,
transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, and Taylor’s theorem.
This course covers symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.
MATH 104 was described as a “good class,” providing “the necessary education
required to pursue a major in math.” However, one student reported that the course was
“difficult, dry and work heavy.” Office hours were highly recommended.
Professor DeTurck was consistently described as “friendly and accessible.” One
student said he “excels in every aspect of structuring and delivering the course.”
However, some students complained that he had trouble “proportioning time to his and
the students’ favor,” forcing him to often “breeze over topics” that required more
explanation. Additionally, some students noted he “assumed some prior knowledge,” and
they felt he did not always explain concepts well.
Many students complained homework “assignments are long and sometimes
aren’t even relevant to the test.” Students agreed that MATH 104 featured “difficult
course material” and that “lots of homework and studying [were] needed.” Students with
strong mathematical backgrounds found the course significantly easier than students
without one.

MATH104 with Professor Rimmer offers a brief review of high school calculus,
applications of integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series,
and Taylor’s theorem. The class utilizes symbolic manipulation and graphics software to
help students visualize important concepts.
Students in general felt the course was “understandable” and “enjoyable.” Most
felt they learned a lot and were able to pick up on the fundamentals of calculus. Some,
however, felt that coverage of certain concepts was incomplete because the class was not
well-paced.
Professor Rimmer received praise from almost all of his students. Multiple
students described him as “the best math teacher” they have had at Penn. Most thought he
was “engaging,” “helpful,” and “approachable.” They also appreciated his sense of
humor. However, a number of students felt that the material was rushed at the end and
they were not given enough time to adequately understand concepts before the final.
The class is primarily intended for underclassmen or students in majors that
require at least one semester of calculus. The class is graded on a curve and the midterms
tended to be quite challenging. Some students pointed out that homework and practice
problems did not sufficiently reflect the difficulty of exam problems. To do well, students
should be able to keep up with what is covered in lecture and have a strong understanding
of assigned problem sets.

This course offers a brief review of High School calculus, applications of
integrals, transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, and Taylor's
theorem. Furthermore, there is the use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in
calculus.
Many students felt as though they did not learn a lot from this class. Several
students stated that it seemed as though one needed to have taken the course before in
order to succeed. Others felt as though it was unfair and that even the review seemed to
be too difficult. Some, students did say that they learned a lot, but these students were
outweighed by those who thought the contrary.
Students found Professor Robinson difficult to follow and an inefficient lecturer.
Students stated that he had trouble presenting his examples in class because it seemed as
though they had not been worked out ahead of time. Despite this, students said that he
was very helpful during office hours and provided new understanding of the material.
Students found this class to be challenging. Many stated that the questions that
appeared on the midterms and finals were nothing like those that had been over in close.
One student stated that “students who took Calculus BC in high school and placed out of
104 thought the tests were impossible.” This class seemed to be too difficult for its
course code.

This course is a brief review of High School calculus, applications of integrals,
transcendental functions, methods of integration, infinite series, and Taylor's theorem.
There is use of symbolic manipulation and graphics software in calculus.
Students generally liked this course although the content was difficult even if AP
Calculus had been taken in high school.
Professor Ghrist was an “entertaining,” “fantastic,” “witty and engaging” teacher.
Many remarked that he made the lectures “interesting to attend,” with one student going
so far as to say that Professor Ghrist could make “anyone look forward to a 9 am class.”
He made a “lasting impression” and “presented the material in an interesting way.” One
student remarked that Professor Ghrist tended to go too fast sometimes, however.
Students thought that this course was “extremely difficult.” It required both “a ton
of foreknowledge” about calculus and “a lot of work.” Most students recommended
having a background in calculus before taking the course. Students remarked that though
the tests were difficult, they were “fair.” Students ended the class “glad” that they had
taken the course and several commented that they would take the class again.
